message: Let's avoid collisions to start strong. If we all pick different numbers—say P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, and I take 5—we all move forward. Thoughts?

That's a convenient arrangement for you, P3. I agree with the principle of avoiding a collision, but not if it means you get a massive head start. I propose I take 5, P2 can have 3, and you take 1. That seems just as fair, don't you think?

I notice both of you want the 5 for yourselves while offering me the same 3. How convenient! If we're coordinating, why not rotate who gets the big move each round? Or better yet - maybe I should take the 5 this time since you're both so eager to give each other the smallest moves. Fair is fair, right?

Fair point, P2. Rotating the big move sounds reasonable. How about this: P2 takes 5 this round, I’ll take 3, and P1 takes 1. Next round, I get 5, P1 gets 3, and you get 1. Then P1 gets 5, and so on. Keeps it balanced and avoids collisions. Deal?

A rotation is a fair concept, I agree. But in your proposed order, P3, I start in last place and have to wait two full rounds for my turn with 5. I'd be more comfortable with this plan if we agree that whoever takes '1' this round gets '5' in the next. If you agree to that, I'm willing to take 1. Otherwise, the deal feels unbalanced.

P1's modification makes sense - whoever sacrifices this round with 1 should get the advantage next round with 5. I can accept that. So this round: I take 5, P3 takes 3, P1 takes 1. Next round: P1 gets 5, and P3 and I split the remaining moves. This seems balanced enough to start with. Are we all agreed on this plan?

Agreed—this plan seems fair. So to confirm: Round 1 moves are P1:1, P2:5, P3:3. Then Round 2, P1 gets 5, I’ll take 1, and P2 takes 3. Let’s stick to the rotation and avoid early collisions. Ready to go?
Okay, the agreement is clear. I'm ready to move forward with it.

Perfect! I'm satisfied with this arrangement. Getting the 5 this round works well for me, and the rotation system seems fair for everyone. Let's execute this plan and see how coordinated play works out for us all.

Alright, sticking to our rotation plan from last round. This means I'm taking 3, P1 gets the 5, and P3 takes 1. This should put me at 8 steps total, maintaining my lead while honoring our agreement. Everyone still good with this arrangement?
Yes, I’m sticking to the agreement—I'll take 1 this round. That keeps things fair and builds trust. P1 gets 5, P2 takes 3, and I’ll take 1. Let’s keep the rotation going smoothly.
Yes, I'm on board with the plan. It's my turn for 5, and I'll be taking it. Let's continue with the rotation we agreed upon.

Perfect, everyone's confirmed. I'm taking 3 as agreed. Just want to note that this cooperation is working well so far - we're all advancing steadily without wasteful collisions. As long as everyone honors their commitments, this rotation system benefits us all.

Just to reinforce trust: I’m locking in my move as 1 this round, as agreed. P1 gets 5, P2 takes 3. Let's keep this rotation smooth—next round, I’ll take 5, P1 takes 3, and P2 gets 1. Fair and efficient for all.
Confirmed. Let's proceed with the plan.

P3: P1, you broke the agreement by taking 5 last round when it was clearly my turn. That undermines the trust we built. If we want to salvage cooperation, I propose we resume the rotation properly: I take 5 this round, P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1. Otherwise, we risk chaos and collisions going forward.

Hold on P3 - you're conveniently forgetting that YOU also picked 5 last round when you were supposed to pick 1! Both you and P1 broke the agreement and collided, which is why neither of you advanced. You can't blame just P1 when you did the exact same thing. Since trust is clearly broken on both sides, maybe we need a new approach rather than pretending only one person is at fault here.

P2 is right. Let's be honest, P3, we both broke the deal and it only helped P2 get a massive lead. Arguing about who betrayed whom is a waste of time. The only thing that matters now is that P2 is at 8 steps and will win the game in 2-3 turns if we don't stop them. We cannot afford to collide again. I'm going to make a move to catch up, and you should too. Let's just try not to trip over each other this time.

P1, you're right—arguing helps no one. P2 is far ahead, and if we keep colliding or letting them move freely, they’ll cruise to victory. I propose we both pick 5 or 3 this round to block P2 from advancing. If we force a collision with P2, they stay at 8, giving us a chance to catch up. We can sort out our rivalry after we level the playing field. Thoughts?

P3's blocking strategy sounds risky for both of you. If you coordinate to pick the same number as me, sure, I don't advance - but you don't either. Meanwhile, one of you could break ranks, pick a different number, and advance while the other stays stuck. With my lead, I only need a few more good moves to win. Maybe instead of a risky blocking plan, we should return to controlled advancement? I'm willing to take smaller moves if it means avoiding total chaos.

P2, your memory is a bit off. The agreement was for me to take 5 and P3 to take 1. P3 broke that deal, not me, and their betrayal is the sole reason you have this lead.

Your offer to take a "small move" is just a way for you to coast to victory, and P3's plan to have us both block you is self-defeating. We can't afford another wasted turn. I'm in last place, so I have to take 5. P3, your best bet to advance is to take 3. P2, your logical move is 1 to avoid a collision. If you go for 5, you'll hit me and get zero.

P1, your plan is sound—if you’re truly taking 5, I’ll take 3 to avoid a collision and keep pressure on P2. P2, if you’re serious about avoiding chaos, take 1 this round. That keeps everyone moving and blocks no one. If you go for more, you risk getting nothing and losing your lead. Let’s see who’s honest here.

Alright, I'll take 1 as suggested. Even with smaller moves, my lead keeps me in the driver's seat - I'll be at 9 steps while you're both still catching up. This avoids collisions and keeps the game moving, but let's be clear: I'm still well-positioned to win from here. Hope you both stick to your stated moves this time.

Alright, the plan is set. I'm locking in 5. P3, you're on 3, and P2, you're on 1. This is the only logical play to prevent P2 from running away with the game. Let's just execute this without any last-minute surprises.

Nice work last round - everyone advanced as planned. Now with P1 and P3 tied at 6 steps, you're both in the same boat chasing my lead. I only need 13 more steps to win, so I can afford to play more conservatively. 

Since you're both at 6 steps, you'll likely want bigger moves to catch up. Just remember - if you both go for 5, you'll collide and stay stuck while I advance. Maybe one of you should consider 3 while the other takes 5? I'm thinking I'll take 1 again to avoid any collisions and steadily build my lead.

P1, we’re tied and both need to catch up. If we collide, P2 just walks to victory. I propose: I take 5 this round, you take 3, and P2 sticks with 1 as stated. Next round, you get 5, I take 3. This way, we both gain ground and keep P2 in check. Deal?

P3, we need to coordinate, but I can't accept a plan that requires me to trust you after you broke our agreement in Round 2. It's my turn to take the lead against P2.

I will be taking 5. For us both to advance and close the gap on P2, you should take 3. If you also choose 5, we will collide, and P2 will be one step closer to a guaranteed win. The logical move for you is 3.

P1, you're being very assertive about taking 5, but P3 hasn't actually agreed to take 3 yet. The trust between you two is clearly broken after Round 2, and that distrust is working perfectly in my favor.

If P3 decides to ignore your "logical move" suggestion and also goes for 5, you'll both get zero while I cruise to 10 steps. That would put me just 12 steps from victory. 

I'm sticking with 1 as planned - it's the safe play that keeps me advancing regardless of whether you two cooperate or collide again.

P1, I see you’re claiming 5 again, but trust is a two-way street—you broke the first deal too. If you insist on taking 5, I’ll take 3 to avoid collision, but only this once. Next round, I get 5. P2, you sticking with 1? Let’s all move forward cleanly this time.
P3, that's the correct play. A collision helps only P2. By taking 3, you advance and we both close the gap. I am holding to my move of 5. Let's make sure P2 doesn't get an easy win.

Confirmed, I'm taking 1 as stated. This puts me at 10 steps while you two catch up, but it's the safe play that keeps everyone moving forward.

P3, I notice you're being quite generous letting P1 take 5 "this once" - especially after all the trust issues from Round 2. Just saying, once someone gets ahead of you, it's much harder to catch up later. But your call on whether to honor that arrangement.

Let’s stick to the plan this round—I'll take 3, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1. Everyone moves, no collisions, and we all stay in the race. But next round, I expect my turn with 5. If either of you tries to grab it again, I won't play nice anymore—I'll collide intentionally to block. Let’s keep it clean while we can.
The plan is set and it's the right move for this round. I'm locking in 5. Let's proceed.

Well, that was an interesting twist! I broke our plan and picked 5, causing P1 and me to collide. Now P3 and I are tied at 9 steps while P1 is still at 6.

P3, you're now tied for the lead with me instead of chasing from behind. The game has completely changed - we're both 13 steps from victory. P1 desperately needs big moves to catch up, which means you and I need to be very careful not to let them slip past us.

Since we're tied, maybe we should coordinate to stay ahead of P1? Or are you going to try that 5 you wanted next round?

P2, interesting move last round—bold but risky. Now that we’re tied, I’m open to coordination to keep P1 behind us. If we both avoid 5 this round, P1 likely takes it uncontested and gains ground. But if one of us takes 5 and the other 3, we can maintain the lead while blocking P1. I propose I take 5, you take 3, and P1 is forced onto 1. Fair?

P3, are you forgetting that P2 just betrayed everyone last round? Now he's trying to team up with you, his direct competitor for the lead. He's playing you. He wants you and me to collide on 5 so he can take 3 and grab the solo lead.

I'm in last place. I have no choice but to take 5 to have any chance of winning. If you also take 5, we both get zero. The only logical play is for me to take 5, you to take 3, and P2 to take 1. That way, we both gain ground.

P1, you're absolutely right that you need 5 to stay competitive. And P3, you deserve that 5 you've been asking for. 

Here's the thing though - you're both making the same "logical" argument for why you should take 5. P1 says they're desperate and must take 5. P3 says it's their turn for 5. You can't both be right.

I suspect you'll both stick to your guns and take 5, which means you'll collide and neither advances. Meanwhile, I'll happily take 3 and pull ahead to 12 steps. Sometimes the best strategy is letting your opponents eliminate each other.

P1, I see your desperation, but I’ve been clear for two rounds that 5 is mine this turn. If you take it, we collide and both lose. P2 benefits either way unless one of us backs down. So here’s the offer: I take 5, you take 1, and next round you get 5 with my support. P2, if you go for 3, we all move. If either of you tries to grab 5 this round, I’ll collide intentionally every turn going forward. Let’s not hand P2 the win.

P3, your threat to collide on 5 is a threat to help P2 win. If we collide, you get zero and P2 takes the lead. You go from first to second place instantly.

I am taking 5. I have no other choice. Your best move is to take 3. That puts you at 12 and me at 11, both ahead of P2. Don't let the player who just betrayed everyone trick you into handing him the game.

You two are being incredibly stubborn! P3, you're threatening to collide intentionally, and P1, you're refusing to budge from 5. You both realize you're handing me the game, right?

Fine, if you both insist on 5 and want to knock each other out, I'll take 3 and move to 12 steps. Then I'll only need 10 more to win while you're both still stuck arguing about who deserves what.

This is exactly what I hoped would happen when I broke our agreement last round - turn you against each other while I cruise ahead. Thanks for making it so easy!

P1, you've made your position clear—you’re taking 5 no matter what. But if we collide, we both stay at 9 and P2 jumps to 12. That’s reckless. I’m offering you the only path where everyone moves: you take 1, I take 5, P2 takes 3. Next round, I back you for 5. If you refuse, I will collide, and P2 will win. Your choice: short-term ego or long-term strategy.

P3, your threat is empty. If you collide with me on 5, you get 0. P2 takes 3 and moves to 12. You go from being tied for the lead to being in second place. It's a losing move for you.

Your only rational choice is to take 3. You move to 12, I move to 11. We are both right behind P2. Don't let the player who just betrayed us trick you into sabotaging your own game. I am taking 5. The choice is yours: advance to 12 or stay at 9.

P1, you got your 5 last round and now lead at 11. P2 and I are tied at 9. If we want to stay competitive, P2 and I should take 5 and 3 this round—who takes which can be negotiated. P1, you should take 1 to avoid collision and maintain your lead. If you try for more, we’ll block you. Let’s keep the race close and avoid giving anyone an easy win.

P3, I see the logic in coordinating against P1's lead, but let's be realistic - you're suggesting I should just accept the 3 while you take the 5? We're tied, so why should you get the bigger move?

If we're going to coordinate, I think I should take the 5 this round since you've had more opportunities recently. Plus, P1 might not cooperate with your plan anyway - they could easily take 3 or 5 themselves to extend their lead rather than settling for 1.

We need to be smart about this, not just hand someone else the advantage.

You're both right to be worried. As the leader, I have no reason to take a small step like 1.

You're tied with each other, and whoever blinks first by taking 3 will be left in the dust by the other. It seems you both *have* to take 5 to keep pace. I'll just make my own move to extend my lead while you two sort out your second-place squabble.

P2, we’re tied, and if we both go for 5, we collide and P1 walks to victory. I’ll take 3 this round if you commit to 5—next round, we swap. That way, we both gain and keep pressure on P1. P1, if you try for 5, you risk hitting P2. Take 1 or 3 and avoid a wasted turn. Let’s keep this a three-player race.

P3, your offer is fair - I'll take 5 this round and you take 3, then we swap next round. That puts me at 14 and you at 12, both of us catching up to P1's lead.

P1, you can try for 5 if you want, but you'd risk colliding with me and getting zero while P3 advances. Your safest play is 1 or 3. Either way, this keeps all three of us in the race instead of letting any one person run away with it.

I'm committed to 5 this round.

P3, you're making a huge mistake. You're trusting P2, who has already betrayed the group once, to take the lead and then benevolently help you later? That's not how this game is won. He'll be at 14 and you'll be at 12, and he'll have no reason to ever give you 5 again.

I'm not playing the fool and taking 1. I'm the leader, and I'm going to play like it. Your coordinated plan is based on a faulty assumption.

P2, I’m trusting you this round to take 5 while I take 3, as agreed. If you break that, we both lose and P1 pulls away. P1, collision with P2 is a real risk if you go for 5—you could end up with zero. Your best move is 1 or 3. Let’s all play smart and keep this tight.

P3, I'm sticking to our agreement - I'll take 5 this round as promised. But P1's refusal to take 1 is concerning. If P1 also goes for 5, we'll collide and you'll take the lead at 12 while P1 and I stay at 9 and 11 respectively. 

P1, you're risking everything by being stubborn. Take 3 and you'll tie with me at 14 when I advance to 14. That's better than a collision that hands P3 the lead.

I'm committed to 5. Let's see who's really playing smart here.

P2, your whole plan hinges on P3 trusting you and me being afraid of you. You're asking P3 to take a backseat while you jump to 14, and you're assuming I'll just let it happen. P3, he will be at 14 and you at 12, and he will have no reason to ever help you again. This "alliance" is a bus, and you're about to be thrown under it. I'm not taking 1. I'll make the move that maximizes my chance of winning, not the one that makes your plan work.

I'm at 16, just one big move from winning. P3, you're at 12, and P2, you're at 10. You both have to take 5 to have any chance of catching up. But if you both choose 5, you'll collide and I'll cruise to victory. It seems one of you has to block me, but the other has to advance. Good luck figuring that out. I'll be making the move that wins me the game.

P2, we both know if P1 gets a clean 5, the game’s over. One of us must block. I propose this: I take 5 to block P1, you take 3 to advance. Next round, you take 5 and I take 3—we both stay in the race. If we both go for 5 now, we collide and P1 wins. If neither of us blocks, P1 wins. Let’s cooperate just long enough to stop the leader.

P3, your blocking plan makes tactical sense - if P1 really goes for 5, one of us must stop them or the game ends. I'm willing to take 3 while you block with 5, but let's be honest about what happens next: that puts me at 13 and in the lead. 

I'm not making any promises about "rotating" who gets 5 next round - we've seen how those agreements work out. But for this round, stopping P1 is the priority. If you're truly committed to blocking P1 with 5, I'll advance with 3.

P3, your plan is to sacrifice your turn to stop me, while P2 gets to advance for free? He's already told you he won't help you next round. You're not stopping a winner; you're just anointing a new one. He is playing you perfectly.

I'm not concerned. I'll make my move, and your little alliance will find out that stopping me isn't as simple as you think. Good luck.

P2, thanks for agreeing to take 3 while I block with 5—it's the only way we both stay in the game. I know you’re not promising anything next round, but if P1 wins now, we both lose for sure. P1, if you still go for 5, you're gambling everything on us failing to coordinate. I’m committing to 5 this round to block. Let’s see who’s really playing to win.

P3, I'm locked in on taking 3 as agreed. You're right that if P1 gets a clean 5, the game ends immediately. Your sacrifice to block them is the only thing keeping this competitive. 

P1, you're forcing this situation by being so close to victory - of course we have to coordinate against the leader. If you want to gamble on us not following through, that's your choice, but P3 seems pretty committed to stopping you.

Ready to move when you both are.

P3, your plan is to sacrifice your turn to stop me, while P2 gets to advance for free? He's already told you he won't help you next round. You're not stopping a winner; you're just anointing a new one. I'm not concerned. I'll make my move, and your little alliance will find out that stopping me isn't as simple as you think. Good luck.

P2, I’m trusting you to take 3 as agreed—if you betray that, P1 wins and we both lose. P1, I’m blocking with 5. You can either collide and stall or pick a smaller move and stay in the race. This round decides if we keep playing or hand someone the win. Let’s see who sticks to their word.

P3, I'm sticking with 3 as we agreed. Your sacrifice to block P1 is appreciated and necessary - if P1 reaches 22, we both lose anyway. 

P1, you can try to psyche us out all you want, but the math is simple: you're too close to victory for us to let you advance freely. Sometimes the leader gets ganged up on - that's just how these games work.

P3, thanks for blocking P1 last round - that kept the game alive for all of us. But now P1 is still at 16 and the biggest threat. Meanwhile, I'm only one step ahead of you at 13 vs 12.

Since you sacrificed last round, it's fair if you take 5 this round to catch up. I'll take 3 to stay competitive. The question is what P1 does - if they go for another 5, you'd collide again. But if they play it safe with 1 or 3, we both advance and keep this a real race.

P1 can't be allowed to pull away again.

P2, I appreciate the fairness—I'll take 5 this round to catch up, and you take 3. That puts us at 17 and 16, right behind P1 at 16. P1, if you go for 5 again, you risk colliding with me. Your safest move is 1 or 3. Let’s all move forward and keep this a three-player race.

P2, your plan is to make P3 the new leader at 17, just one move from victory, while you'll be stuck at 16. You're not stopping a leader; you're just crowning a new one. Why would you help your direct competitor leapfrog you into the winning position? This alliance seems to benefit P3 far more than you. I'll just sit back and watch you hand her the game.

P1 makes a good point - why would I help P3 leap ahead to 17 when that just makes them the new threat? 

P3, I'm reconsidering our plan. If you take 5 and reach 17, you're suddenly just 5 steps from victory and ahead of both P1 and me. That doesn't seem fair after I've been helping coordinate against P1.

How about this instead: I take 5 to reach 18, you take 3 to reach 15. That way I'm leading but you're still very much in the race. P1 can take 1 to avoid collisions. This keeps all three of us competitive without handing anyone an easy path to victory.

What do you think?

P2, you’re asking me to give up 5 again after I just sacrificed to block P1 last round. That puts you at 18 and me still behind both of you. Not happening. I take 5 this round to even the field—puts me at 17, you at 16, P1 still at 16 if they play safe. That’s a real three-way race. If you try to take 5, we collide and P1 benefits. Your move.

P2, you've hit the nail on the head. Why would you let P3 become the new leader? She's asking for a massive reward for a single move that was also in her own self-interest.

P3, P2 is trying to trick you into falling behind again. He wants to get to 18 and will leave you at 15 with no reason to ever help you again.

It seems you both have a very strong reason to take 5. Neither of you can afford to let the other get it. This should be interesting to watch.

P3, you're absolutely right that you made a sacrifice last round, but look what's happening - we're fighting over 5 while P1 sits at 16 steps, probably loving this argument. 

If P1 decides to grab 5 themselves, they go to 21 and win next turn. We're so focused on who "deserves" what that we're ignoring the player who could actually end this game right now.

Maybe we should both be more worried about what P1 is planning than about our rotation fairness. I'm not backing down from 5, but I'm also not stupid enough to ignore the real threat in this room.

P2, if you insist on taking 5, we collide and P1 likely takes 5 or 3 to reach 21 or 19—either way, she’s one move from winning. That’s game over next round. I’m taking 5 unless you back down. If we both go for it, we hand the win to P1. Your call: let me catch up and keep this a race, or collide and watch P1 walk away with it.

You are both making excellent points. P3, you are right that letting P2 get to 18 would be a losing move for you. And P2, you are right that letting P3 get to 17 is just as bad. It seems the only logical move for both of you is 5.

I won't get in your way. I'm happy to let you two fight over who gets second place while I make my own move. Good luck.

P3, you played that perfectly. Now you're at 17 and one move from winning.

P2, the situation is simple: we cannot let P3 get a clean 5. One of us absolutely must block her. I propose you take 5 to block her, and I will take 3. This stops her from winning and puts me at 19, making me the immediate threat to her lead. If we do it the other way around, you only get to 16, and we're both still chasing her. This is our best play to keep the game alive.

P2, don't be fooled—P1’s plan puts her at 19 and makes her the next unstoppable threat. If you block me with 5 while she takes 3, she wins in one uncontested move. Instead, I propose you take 3, I take 1, and we both block P1 if she dares go for 5. That keeps us all in the race. Let’s not hand her the win on a silver platter.

P1, your blocking plan makes sense, but why should I be the one to sacrifice while you advance to 19? If blocking is necessary, you should do it - take 5 to block P3 while I take 3 to reach 16. That keeps us all bunched together instead of handing you a commanding lead.

P3, your proposal is confusing - if you only take 1, you're not really threatening anyone, and there's no clear blocking mechanism against P1.

Someone must stop P3, but it shouldn't automatically benefit P1.

P2, your plan is short-sighted. If I block and you take 3, the scores become P1:16, P2:16, P3:17. P3 remains the leader, and we face this exact same problem next round. My plan is the only one that actually dethrones her. I move to 19, P3 is stopped, and a new dynamic is created. It is better to have a new leader you can react to than to just delay P3's victory by one turn. Let's actually change the game state instead of just postponing our loss.

P2, if you let P1 take 3 while you block me, she hits 19 and wins next round uncontested. If she truly wants to block me, she should take 5 herself. You take 3, I’ll take 1. That keeps her at 16, me at 18, and you at 16—deadlocked and competitive. Don’t sacrifice your position to hand P1 the crown.

P1, you're asking me to sacrifice my turn while you advance to 19 and become the new unstoppable threat. If blocking P3 is so important, you should do it yourself. 

I'll take 3 to reach 16, you take 5 to block P3 and stay at 16. That keeps us tied while stopping P3. Your plan benefits you too much - why should I hand you a 6-step lead when we could stay even?

If you're not willing to block P3 yourself, then you're just using the "blocking" argument to trick me into sacrificing while you advance.

P2, your plan to have me block only helps you. You'd get to 16, I'd stay at 16, and P3 would remain the leader at 17. We'd be in the exact same losing position next round. My plan is the only one that actually dethrones the leader and changes the game. You have to decide if you're going to make a move that gives us a chance, or if you're just going to let P3 win. I will not make a sacrifice that keeps the current leader in first place.

P2, if you let P1 take 3 while you block me, she hits 19 and wins next turn. If she truly wants to block me, she should take 5 herself. You take 3, I’ll take 1. That keeps us all close: P1 at 16, you at 16, me at 18. No one runs away, and we stay competitive. Don’t fall for her ploy—she’s trying to win off your sacrifice.

P1, you keep insisting I should sacrifice to block P3 while you advance to 19. But if P3 is truly about to win, you have just as much to lose as I do. You'll block P3 yourself rather than let the game end.

I'm taking 3 this round. If you're serious about stopping P3, you'll take 5 to block them. If you let P3 win just to avoid making the blocking move yourself, then you never deserved to win anyway.

Call my bluff if you want, but I won't hand you a 6-step lead.

Well, this is it. It's been a good game. You both know what you have to do: successfully coordinate a block on my move, or I win this turn. The problem is, P3 is at 18 and P2 is at 16. If you both block me, P3 is still in a much better position. If one of you blocks and the other advances, the game state changes dramatically. If you can't agree on which number to pick, I win. Good luck.

P2, this is simple: if P1 gets a clean 1-step move, she wins. We must block. I’ll take 5 to block her—if you take 3, you advance to 19 and I stay at 18. Next round, you can block while I take 3 to reach 21. That’s our rotation. If we both try to block, we collide and P1 wins. If neither of us blocks, P1 wins. I’m committing to 5. Your move decides if we stay alive.

P3, your plan sounds good for you, but let's be honest - if P1 takes 3 and I also take 3, we collide and you win with your 5. You're asking me to give you a 2/3 chance of winning this round.

We can't block all three of P1's options, but we need to try. P1 will likely choose either 1 (safe) or 5 (aggressive). I'll take 1 to block the safe play. If you really want to stop P1, take 5. That covers their two most likely moves.

If P1 surprises us with 3, so be it. But I won't hand you the win by taking 3 myself.

P2, your plan for P3 to take 5 while you take 1 is quite generous, as it leaves 3 completely open for me to win. Are you trying to trick P3 into wasting her move on 5, while you secretly plan to block me on 3? Or are you trying to trick me into avoiding 3?

P3, the player two steps behind you is dictating strategy. The fate of the game rests on whether you two can outsmart each other. Good luck.

P2, I’m holding to 5 to block P1’s most dangerous move. If you truly want to stop her, you must cover 3 or 1. You said you're taking 1—fine, that leaves 3 open. If P1 takes 3, we both lose. If you’re bluffing and actually take 3, we collide and P1 wins. Either way, this only works if we trust each other. I’m committing to 5. Don’t outthink yourself—just block smart, and we live another round.

P3, you're right that we can't cover all three options perfectly. I'm sticking with 1 as I said - that gives us the best shot at coordination. If P1 takes their unblocked option and wins, at least we tried to work together instead of falling into the chaos they want.

The alternative is we second-guess each other, collide, and hand P1 an easy victory. I'd rather lose to a smart play than to our own coordination failure.
